> But I suspect that the people who discovered Design
> Patterns/XP/Refacto=
ring might have some idea on Object 
> Oriented design ;-)

And I suspect t=
hat in that remark lies the crux of it.  The common
topics that appear when=
 discussing the complexity of JUnit are Suites
and Tests, where this is jus=
t a typical instantiation of the Composite
pattern.  The TestResult is a co=
llecting parameter, and so on.

I am one of those people who puts JUnit for=
ward as an example to be
followed, and am, so far, unswayed from that posit=
ion.  My views are
based on the code for JUnit 3.7, but I can only imagine =
that it has
gotten better, and not worse in the latest release.

As is usua=
lly the case when using patterns in code, to the non-initiated
any such cod=
e may look very complex indeed, and the relationships
between the different=
 classes unfathomable.  The benefits for those who
do recognise the pattern=
s, however, is great.

Manuel Amago.
